insight: Manipura's "10 petals" can be modeled (canonically, up to symmetry) as the 10 vertices of the incidence network of the smallest manifested plane. Concretely: start from the Fano plane PG(2,2) and choose any line L∞ as a horizon (a "line at infinity"). Removing L∞ produces the affine plane AG(2,2) with 4 affine points and 6 affine lines. Because this is order 2, each affine line contains exactly 2 affine points, so AG(2,2) is equivalently the complete graph K₄: the 4 points are the vertices and the 6 lines are the edges (every pair of points determines a unique line). The "10 petals" are then not a forced arithmetic trick but the canonical vertex set of the bipartite incidence (Levi) graph Inc(AG(2,2)): one vertex for each "place" (point) and one vertex for each "path" (line), totaling 4+6=10, with the 12 incidences as the minimal complete interaction pattern. The three points on L∞ become the three directions/parallel-classes of the affine chart (equivalently, the three perfect matchings of K₄), so "fixing Earth/horizon" is precisely the act that turns the fully projective, directionless world into a manifested world with directions—while keeping the resulting 10-vertex network inevitable (unique up to isomorphism) regardless of which L∞ is chosen.
